etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French escharre, via late Latin from Greek eskhara ‘scab’

definitions: a mark left on the skin or within body tissue where a wound, burn, or sore has not healed completely and fibrous connective tissue has developed

examples.text: a faint scar ran the length of his left cheek

shortDefinitions: mark left on skin or within body tissue where wound

definitions: a lasting effect of grief, fear, or other emotion left on a person's character by a traumatic experience

examples.text: the attack has left mental scars on Terry and his family

definitions: a mark left on something following damage of some kind

examples.text: Max could see scars of the blast

shortDefinitions: mark left on something following damage of some kind

definitions: a mark left at the point of separation of a leaf, frond, or other part from a plant

examples.text: this fossil bark is typified by its lozenge-shaped leaf scars

shortDefinitions: mark left at point of separation of leaf

definitions: a steep high cliff or rock outcrop, especially of limestone
etymologies: Middle English: from Old Norse sker ‘low reef’

examples.text: high limestone scars bordered the road

shortDefinitions: steep high cliff or rock outcrop

definitions: mark with a scar or scars

examples.text: he is likely to be scarred for life after injuries to his face, arms, and legs

definitions: form or be marked with a scar.
shortDefinitions: form or be marked with scar
